document.masterDocTitle: New records of pyraloid moths (Lepidoptera: Pyraloidea) from different regions of Ukraine

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New records of pyraloid moths (Lepidoptera: Pyraloidea) from different regions of Ukraine

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–2. Adults of
Pyralis cardinalis
. 1. ♂, Kyiv region, prep. no. 303/20. 2. ♀, Kyiv region, prep. no. 503.21.

FIGURES 3–5. Genitalia of
Pyralis cardinalis
. 3a, 4a. Male genitalia, aedeagus separated. 3b, 4b. Aedeagus, vesica everted. 5. Female genitalia. 3a–b. ♂, Kyiv region, prep. no. 303/20 (courtesy photographed by Oleksiy Bidzilya). 4a–b. ♂, Kyiv region, prep. no. 522.21. 5. ♀, Kyiv region, prep. no. 503.21.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution : probably from W Europe to European part of Russia , known from Lower Volga region of Russia (E. Tsvetkov, pers. comm.); distribution requires clarification due to the problem of distinguishing between
Elegia fallax ( Staudinger, 1881 )
and
E. atrifasciella
. In Ukraine : Chernihiv ( Panasyura & Govorun 2012 : as
E . atrifasciella
), Kharkiv (
Karolinskiy et al . 2019
: as
E . fallax
, after re-identification—
E . atrifasciella
(Karolinskiy et al . (in press)), Mykolaiv & Kherson (Black Sea Reserve) ( Zelinska 1959 : as
E . atrifasciella
; Zelinska 1961 : as
E . atrifasciella
, 1977: as
E . atrifasciella
), Kherson ( Govorun 2008a : as
E . fallax
), Zaporizhzhia & Donetsk (
Bidzilya et al . 2001
: as
E . atrifasciella
), Donetsk ( Pak 1998a : as
E . atrifasciella
), Luhansk ( Pak 1998a : as
E . atrifasciella
; Pak & Yaroshenko 2001b : as
E . atrifasciella
;
Demyanenko et al . 2018
: as
E . fallax
) regions and Crimea ( Budashkin 2004 : as
E . fallax
),
first records for Kyiv and Odesa regions
.

Remark . Roesler (1988) synonymized
Elegia atrifasciella
with
E. fallax
, thus, records from Ukraine cited between 1988 and 2019 as
E. fallax
require verification, as Slamka (2019: 25) proved that
E. atrifasciella
is a distinct species. So far, we have not found
E. fallax
in the territory of Ukraine . All findings of these two species should be verified by examination of the genitalia. The recently described species from the Balkans,
Elegia occultalis Plant, 2020
(
Plant et al . 2020
) can be confused with the two abovementioned species, however, it is distinguished by the male genitalia.
Elegia occultalis
has not been found in Ukraine .
